channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pelosi’s Husband Is Gravely Injured in Hammer Attack by an Intruder
item.description: As leaders from across the political spectrum rushed to condemn the attack, Paul Pelosi underwent surgery to repair a skull fracture.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning, Tim Arango, Luke Broadwater and Holly Secon
item.media:description: Police and investigators at Speaker Nancy Pelosi's San Francisco residence, where her husband, Paul Pelosi, was attacked by an intruder early Friday morning.

item.title: Politicized Rantings on Two Blogs by a ‘daviddepape’ Draw Scrutiny
item.description: The San Francisco district attorney is investigating hateful comments.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer and Kellen Browning
item.media:description: Paul Pelosi in Washington in 2020. Mr. Pelosi’s wife, Speaker Nancy Pelosi, has often been a target of anger from opposing political parties throughout her career.

item.title: Officers responded so rapidly to Paul Pelosi’s 911 call that they witnessed the attack, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning and Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: The scene outside the home of Paul and Nancy Pelosi in San Francisco, hours after an assailant broke in and attacked Mr. Pelosi. The authorities identified the suspect as David DePape, 42.

item.title: Elon Musk Starts Putting His Imprint on Twitter
item.description: The billionaire began as Twitter’s new owner by announcing a content moderation council and meeting employees, as some of the social media service’s users celebrated.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Lauren Hirsch and Ryan Mac
item.media:description: Elon Musk closed his $44 billion deal to buy the social media service on Thursday night.

item.title: Antisemitic campaign tries to capitalize on Elon Musk’s Twitter takeover.
item.description: The campaign appeared to start after Mr. Musk had officially taken control of the company.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:description: Mr. Musk has promised to loosen content moderation rules on Twitter in the name of “free speech.”

item.title: The Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, Dynamic Harlem Pastor, Dies at 73
item.description: He led Abyssinian Baptist Church and helped revitalize his community by building housing, some of which he reserved for existing residents.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: The Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, the longtime pastor of Abyssinian Baptist Church, at his office in Harlem in 1999.

item.title: Jerry Lee Lewis, a Rock ’n’ Roll Original, Dies at 87
item.description: With his pounding piano, his impassioned vocals and his incendiary performing style, Mr. Lewis lived up to his nickname, the Killer.
item.dc:creator: William Grimes
item.media:description: Jerry Lee Lewis in 1957. His incendiary performing style captured the essence of rock rebellion.

item.title: Jerry Lee Lewis: Listen to 10 Songs From a Rock ’n’ Roll Pioneer
item.description: From “Great Balls of Fire” to “Over the Rainbow,” whether the songs were brash or tearful, Jerry Lee Lewis was indomitable.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:credit: Ron Galella Collection via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jerry Lee Lewis in the late 1980s. His music, even when he was making it within the Nashville country establishment in the 1960s and 1970s, chafed at confinement

item.title: Scarred by War, Ukraine’s Children Face Years of Trauma
item.description: For countless Ukrainian children, the war has brought long-term physical and psychological injuries. Those who have suffered serious physical harm or the loss of a parent now face a challenging path forward.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maryna Ponomariova, 6, whose left leg had to be amputated below the knee after a devastating attack on her home in Kherson, is now learning to walk again with the help of Nazar Borozniuk at Ohmadyt Children’s Hospital in Kviv, Ukraine, earlier this month.

item.title: Ukraine’s Army Advances Toward Kherson, as Mud Season Arrives
item.description: Fall rains have turned the earth to sludge, slowing advances at least until the winter freeze, in conditions that have hampered military movement for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier passing the window of a school that was used as a base by Russian forces in Velyka Oleksandrivka, in the Kherson region of Ukraine.

item.title: Obama to Georgia Democrats: ‘Resist the Temptation to Give Up’
item.description: The former president is hitting the campaign trail, beginning in Georgia on Friday night, to try to help Democrats energize voters and regain momentum in key Senate races.
item.dc:creator: Maya King and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama campaigned for Democratic candidates in Georgia on Friday night in Atlanta, saying “I’m here to tell you that tuning out is not an option.”

item.title: Bennet and O’Dea Battle Over Abortion and Guns in Final Colorado Senate Debate
item.description: The exchange was testier than an earlier debate this week, as the Republican challenger, Joe O’Dea, attacked Senator Michael Bennet, a Democrat, as “ineffective” and Mr. Bennet branded his rival “a liar.”
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado, left, and Joe O’Dea, a Republican, during a debate in Fort Collins, Colo., on Friday.

item.title: Dark Tourism: Destinations of Death, Tragedy and the Macabre
item.description: Travelers who use their off time to visit places like the Chernobyl nuclear plant or current conflict zones say they no longer want a sanitized version of a troubled world.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Aokigahara forest in Japan, known as the suicide forest, is a dark tourism destination.

item.title: The Pelosis and a Haunted America
item.description: Gruesome Republicans are writing our national horror story.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:description: Nancy and Paul Pelosi in 1987. They have been married for 59 years.

item.title: Congress Should Back This Promising Bill on Immigration
item.description: Congress needs to provide sufficient funding for an asylum system that admits those who qualify for refuge and keeps out those who don’t.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Illustration by Rebecca Chew/The New York Times; photograph by MasterLu, via Getty Images

item.title: Elon Musk Is Buying Twitter. Shudder.
item.description: Rogue billionaires have appeared before, and they will appear again. But this one will control our “digital town square.”
item.dc:creator: David Nasaw

item.title: How China Is Fighting the Chip War With America
item.description: The battle for technological superiority between the United States and China is the ultimate competition between two radically different systems.
item.dc:creator: Keyu Jin
item.media:credit: Noel Celis/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A member of security staff inside the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: San Francisco Police and F.B.I. agents outside the home where Paul Pelosi was attacked.

item.title: Inside the Minds of Four Grass-roots Conservative Voters
item.description: Inside the minds of four American conservative voters, whose political priorities revolve around defending the country.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

item.title: When You’re Sick at Home
item.description: Your guide to eating well, even when you’re feeling low.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson
item.media:credit: Ben Russell for The New York Times
item.media:description: The smoked brisket pho from Lucy’s Vietnamese in Brooklyn makes for a perfect recovery meal.

item.title: How Is Your Company Responding to Labor Organizing? We Want to Hear.
item.description: Employers are taking a variety of approaches to union campaigns.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: DeSean McClinton-Holland for The New York Times; Tony Luong for The New York Times

item.title: Ex-Capitol Police Officer Found Guilty of Obstruction in Jan. 6 Case
item.description: A jury found that the man, Michael A. Riley, 51, had deleted Facebook messages in which he offered advice to a Jan. 6 rioter about how to avoid getting caught, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.category: Riley, Michael A (US Capitol Police Officer)
item.media:credit: Tom Williams/Roll Call, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Officer Michael Riley outside Capitol Police headquarters after being named Officer of the Month for February 2011 by the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund. He was convicted Friday of obstruction of justice in connection with the Jan. 6 riot.

item.title: Bad News for the Fed As Inflation and Wages Continue to Climb Rapidly
item.description: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation measure showed that price gains remained fast in September, and a gauge of wages it watches closely is climbing quickly.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers in New York this week. Friday’s Personal Consumption Expenditures report underlined that for now, demand remains strong.

item.title: Kanye West Faces Costly Fallout
item.description: The entertainer has been widely condemned for a series of antisemitic comments. The fallout across industries has been swift.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kanye West at a fashion show held by Vogue in September in New York.

item.title: In Retrial, Man Who Helped Run Border Wall Charity Is Convicted
item.description: Timothy Shea was the only one of four defendants in the federal case to face a jury. The former Trump adviser Stephen K. Bannon faces similar charges in state court.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.media:description: Timothy Shea was a central figure in raising $25 million for a barrier separating the United States from Mexico.

item.title: How to Help Someone With Depression
item.description: Whether they are coping with seasonal symptoms or chronic depression, here’s how to offer love and understanding while still caring for yourself.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: How Love Languages Became a Cultural Phenomenon
item.description: The author of the seminal book on love languages is surprised that the concept has become a cultural phenomenon. But he still wants couples to heed his advice.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Luis Mazón

item.title: Terrence Real’s Latest Book Explores Fixing What Ails Us
item.description: In his new book, ‘Us’, Terrence Real explores how ‘enlightened self interest’ could save your relationship.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Jones

item.title: How Online Dating Apps Can Lead to Burnout
item.description: Ten years after the launch of Tinder, some long-term online daters say endless swiping has been bad for their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: Allow Natalia Lafourcade to Reintroduce Herself
item.description: After years of recording homages to Latin American greats, the Mexican singer-songwriter re-emerges with an LP that features new collaborators, including Marc Ribot.
item.dc:creator: Ed Morales
item.media:credit: Dana Golan for The New York Times
item.media:description: “De Todas las Flores” (“Of All the Flowers”) is Natalia Lafourcade’s first album of all-original material since her Grammy-winning 2015 LP, “Hasta la Raíz” (“To the Root”).

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
